content:
We scan the IPv4 address space for open DNS servers supporting DNS-over-TLS (DoT, RFC 7858), DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH, RFC 8484), DNS-over-QUIC (DoQ, RFC 9250), and DoH3.
Here we provide statistics and lists of open encrypted DNS servers, including their IP addresses, authentication domain names (ADN), locations, and certificate verification status.
Our scan is performed monthly and dates back to December 2021.
Related publications: [IMC ‘19] Chaoyi Lu, Baojun Liu, Zhou Li, Shuang Hao, Haixin Duan, Mingming Zhang, Chunying Leng, Ying Liu, Zaifeng Zhang, and Jianping Wu. An End-to-End, Large-Scale Measurement of DNS-over-Encryption: How Far Have We Come?. In Proceedings of the 2019 ACM Internet Measurement Conference Paper Cite IRTF Applied Networking Research Prize Recepient
[ToN ‘23] Ruixuan Li, Xiaofeng Jia, Zhenyong Zhang, Jun Shao, Rongxing Lu, Jingqiang Lin, Xiaoqi Jia, Guiyi Wei. A Longitudinal and Comprehensive Measurement of DNS Strict Privacy. In IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking Paper Cite
Statistics and summary: A) Count of IPs and ADNs of encrypted DNS servers: B) Validity of certificates Raw data: Here we provide open access to raw data that lags one month behind. Drop us an email if you need the most recent scanning results.
Date DoT servers DoH servers DoQ servers DoH3 servers Oct, 2023 dot-202310.json doh-202310.json doq-202310.json doh3-202310.json Apr, 2023 dot-202304.json doh-202304.json doq-202304.json doh3-202304.json
summary:
We scan the IPv4 address space for open DNS servers supporting DNS-over-TLS (DoT, RFC 7858), DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH, RFC 8484), DNS-over-QUIC (DoQ, RFC 9250), and DoH3.
Here we provide statistics and lists of open encrypted DNS servers, including their IP addresses, authentication domain names (ADN), locations, and certificate verification status.
title: Open Encrypted DNS Servers

content:
DNS turns 40 this year! We maintain an up-to-date repository of DNS-related RFCs. To help community members quickly gather documents of interest, we also give finer-grained labels under particular topics (e.g., DNSSEC, IDNA, DNS privacy) to each RFC.
What’s within the list:
Documents subsequent to RFC 882 (November 1983) DNS specification: namespace, name registration, DNS protocol DNS operation: functionalities and recommendations about running DNS services DNS security: security extensions, threat analysis, and proposed solutions DNS use: Internet functionalities that explicitly rely on the DNS (e.g., SPF, DANE) Obsoleted/deprecated versions of the above The list updates once a month. It now includes 42 RFCs under 42 labels.
Comments or suggestions are extremely welcome! Drop us an email if you think an RFC is missing, mis-labeled, should be removed, or if you have any other feedback.

title: DNS RFC Repository

content:
We maintain profiles of large public DNS services, including basic info and state of support for DNS functionalities.
Results of this page come from real tests - we develop a customized infrastructure (open-sourced at Github), including a stub and authoritative server, to test the functionalities. Links to official documents are also provided where available.
summary:
We maintain profiles of large public DNS services, including basic info and state of support for DNS functionalities.
Results of this page come from real tests - we develop a customized infrastructure (open-sourced at Github), including a stub and authoritative server, to test the functionalities.
title: Public DNS service profile
TEST
